awd_titl_txt: Typological and historical discovery through language documentation of Walman, Srenge, Aro, and Eho, four critically endangered languages
awd_abstract_narration:
About one fifth of the languages of the world (that is, over 1200 languages) are spoken in New Guinea. This is more than all the languages of mainland Europe and Asia combined. Yet fewer than 5% of the languages of New Guinea have been described in any detail and for the majority, we know next to nothing. We know from past experience that New Guinean languages exhibit rare typological features through which we can understand better how language changes through time and how language systems are organized.  We must document these features now as many of the languages of New Guinea are seriously endangered and are no longer being learned by young children. Probably a majority of the languages of New Guinea will be extinct or almost extinct by the end of this century. Language is the most complex form of human behavior, but for every language that become extinct, we forever lose knowledge about this essential part of what it means to be human. 
  
Matthew Dryer of SUNY at Buffalo along with linguist Pamela Brown and two graduate students will conduct fieldwork in northern New Guinea in or near the Torricelli Mountains.   They will complete or create dictionaries, grammars and texts collections for four languages, Walman, Srenge, Aro, and Eho, all of which are of the Torricelli group.   The documentation will include descriptions of complex verbal conjunction, typologically unusual infixation patterns, and variations in word order that are determined by the object's thematic role.  

The data collected from this project will be accessible from the Endangered Languages Archive.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
The NSF grant for which this report is reporting the outcomes of has been part of a larger project documenting endangered languages in Papua New Guinea. Approximately one sixth of the languages of the world (over 1000) are spoken in New Guinea, most of them both endangered and undocumented. When languages die, part of the culture of the speakers of those language dies as well. The people of New Guinea value what linguists are doing in documenting their languages and helping to slow down if not stop the loss of their languages. The larger project focuses on one area in northwest Papua New Guinea and had already produced detailed descriptions of two languages under previous grants. The part of the project funded by the NSF grant for which this report is reporting outcomes is providing descriptions of six additional languages. One has already been completed, three are nearly completed and two others are partly done. Five of the six languages that have been documented under the current grant are in the same language family (the Torricelli family), one of about ten language families in the world with over 50 languages, but prior to the current project, was by far the worst documented of these large language families.

 

All of the languages being documented under the current grant are spoken by people living in communities largely unaffected by modern civilization. The villages have no access to electricity, they have no forms of plumbing, and their way of life has not changed much from the way it was a thousand years ago. They are able to grow their own food, though their diets are often protein-deficient. A photograph of the traditional house that the leader of this project lived in early in the research, as well as a photo of a village man from a video recording of him telling a story, are attached to this report. Apart from producing detailed grammatical descriptions of all of these languages, the project is producing dictionaries for some of these languages, extensive audio recordings of people telling stories in their language and video recordings of people telling stories and other cultural events in their communities. These are all valued by the communities and will be available for them in the future when they have access to the internet. These materials will also be available (and in many cases already are available) to the general public, allowing them to learn more about these people.

 


Last Modified: 02/27/2024
Modified by: Matthew S Dryer
